hints_html:
Try to write the sum above in summation notations (using \(\Sigma\)). Do you recognize a pattern?

f(x) is the limit of a left Riemann sum and can hence be represented as an integral. Try to find that integral expression.

Recall that the general form of a (left) Riemann sum is

\[\begin{aligned} \int_a^b f(y)\,dy = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \Delta y\,f(y_j),\end{aligned}\]

where \(y_j = a + j\Delta y\) and \(\Delta y = \frac{b-a}{n}\).
hints_latex:
Try to write the sum above in summation notations (using $\Sigma$). Do
you recognize a pattern?

\emph{f(x)} is the limit of a left Riemann sum and can hence be
represented as an integral. Try to find that integral expression.
hints_raw:
Try to write the sum above in summation notations (using <math>\Sigma</math>). Do you recognize a pattern?
''f(x)'' is the limit of a left Riemann sum and can hence be represented as an integral. Try to find that integral expression.
Recall that the general form of a (left) Riemann sum is

:<math>
\int_a^b f(y)\,dy = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \Delta y\,f(y_j),
</math>

where <math> y_j = a + j\Delta y</math> and <math> \Delta y = \frac{b-a}{n} </math>.
sols_html:
We can recognize this as the limit of a Riemann sum. Let’s first put this into summation notation:

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2 + (1+j(x-1)/n)^3} \cdot \frac{x-1}{n}\end{aligned}\]

Note that when \(j=0\) this gives us the 1/3 term in the sum. We put the factor \((x-1)/n\) first to resemble the general form of a (left) Riemann sum as given in Hint 3.

Ultimately, we aim to express \(f(x)\) as a definite integral i.e. something of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \int_a^b g(s) ds = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} g(s_j) \cdot \Delta s\end{aligned}\]

We choose \(s\) here for ease of notation and not overuse the \(x\) symbol.

For \(x\) fixed, we can read off an interval spacing of

\[\begin{aligned} \Delta s = \frac{x-1}{n}\end{aligned}\]

Let’s rewrite the sum with \(\Delta s\) in place of \((x-1)/n\):

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2+(1+j \Delta s)^3} \cdot \Delta s.\end{aligned}\]

This is suggestive of a left-endpoint Riemann sum, since we start with \(j=0\) and end at \(j=n-1\). In that case, we can take our subinterval endpoints to be \(s_j = 1+ j \Delta s\) (recall that when we do a Riemann sum, we have subintervals with endpoints that look like \(s_j = a + j \Delta s\) and terms of the form \(1 + j \Delta s\) are of this form).

Let’s rewrite this as

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2 + s_j^3} \cdot \Delta s\end{aligned}\]

From here, we read off

\[\begin{aligned} g(s) = \frac{1}{2+s^3}\end{aligned}\]

Also, since \(s_0 = 1 + 0 \Delta s = 1\) is the lower bound and \(s_n = 1 + n \Delta s = 1 + n (x-1)/n = x\) is the upper bound, our final result is that

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \int_1^x \frac{1}{2+s^3} ds\end{aligned}\]

Finally we can compute the equation of the tangent line to \(f(x)\) at \(x=1\). All we need are \(f(1)\) and \(f'(1)\).

\[\begin{aligned} f(1) = \int_1^1 g(s) ds = 0\end{aligned}\]

since we are integrating over a range of zero.

And by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{1}{2+x^3}\end{aligned}\]

so

\[\begin{aligned} f'(1) = \frac{1}{3}\end{aligned}\]

Hence the equation of the tangent line is

\[\begin{aligned} y-0 = \frac{1}{3}(x-1)\end{aligned}\]

or simply

\[\begin{aligned} y = \frac{1}{3} (x-1)\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We can recognize this as the limit of a Riemann sum. Let's first put this into summation notation:

:<math>
f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2 + (1+j(x-1)/n)^3} \cdot \frac{x-1}{n}
</math>

Note that when <math>j=0</math> this gives us the 1/3 term in the sum. We put the factor <math>(x-1)/n</math> first to resemble the general form of a (left) Riemann sum as given in Hint 3.

Ultimately, we aim to express <math>f(x)</math> as a definite integral i.e. something of the form
:<math>
\int_a^b g(s) ds = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1}  g(s_j) \cdot \Delta s
</math>
We choose <math>s</math> here for ease of notation and not overuse the <math>x</math> symbol.

For <math>x</math> fixed, we can read off an interval spacing of
:<math>
\Delta s = \frac{x-1}{n}
</math>
Let's rewrite the sum with <math>\Delta s</math> in place of <math>(x-1)/n</math>:

:<math>f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2+(1+j \Delta s)^3} \cdot \Delta s</math>.

This is suggestive of a left-endpoint Riemann sum, since we start with <math>j=0</math> and end at <math>j=n-1</math>. In that case, we can take our subinterval endpoints to be <math>s_j = 1+ j \Delta s</math> (recall that when we do a Riemann sum, we have subintervals with endpoints that look like <math>s_j = a + j \Delta s</math> and terms of the form <math>1 + j \Delta s</math> are of this form).

Let's rewrite this as
:<math>
f(x) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2 + s_j^3} \cdot \Delta s
</math>

From here, we read off
:<math>
g(s) = \frac{1}{2+s^3}
</math>

Also, since <math>s_0 = 1 + 0 \Delta s = 1</math> is the lower bound and <math>s_n = 1 + n \Delta s = 1 + n (x-1)/n = x</math> is the upper bound, our final result is that
:<math>
f(x) = \int_1^x \frac{1}{2+s^3} ds
</math>

Finally we can compute the equation of the tangent line to <math>f(x)</math> at <math>x=1</math>. All we need are <math>f(1)</math> and <math>f'(1)</math>.
:<math>
f(1) = \int_1^1 g(s) ds = 0
</math>
since we are integrating over a range of zero.

And by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
:<math>
f'(x) = \frac{1}{2+x^3}
</math>
so
:<math>
f'(1) = \frac{1}{3}
</math>

Hence the equation of the tangent line is
:<math>
y-0 = \frac{1}{3}(x-1)
</math>
or simply
:<math>
y = \frac{1}{3} (x-1)
</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left[ \left\{ \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{x-1}{n} \right)^3} + \frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{2(x-1)}{n} \right)^3} + \ldots \right.\right.\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \ldots + \left.\left.\frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{(n-1)(x-1)}{n} \right)^3} \right\} \frac{x-1}{n} \right]\end{aligned}\]

where x \(\geq\) 0. Find the equation of the tangent line to the graph y = f(x) at x = 1.
statement_raw:
Let
:<math>
f(x) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left[ \left\{ \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{x-1}{n} \right)^3} + \frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{2(x-1)}{n} \right)^3} + \ldots \right.\right.
</math>
::::::::::<math>
\ldots + \left.\left.\frac{1}{2+\left( 1+\frac{(n-1)(x-1)}{n} \right)^3} \right\} \frac{x-1}{n} \right]
</math>
where ''x'' ≥ 0. Find the equation of the tangent line to the graph ''y'' = ''f''(''x'') at ''x'' = 1.
